name: Blues
description: Originated toward the end of the 19th century in African American communities in the United States, particularly the Deep South; drew on traditional Spirituals and Work Song; highly influential to the whole of Western popular music.

sub_genres.name: Acoustic Blues
sub_genres.description: Developed out of Work Song and Spirituals to become the most prominent early form of Blues.

sub_genres.name: Boogie Woogie
sub_genres.description: Early, uptempo Blues featuring the piano as the main instrument, with soloing and improvisation played over the top of a repetitive eight note bassline.

sub_genres.name: Country Blues
sub_genres.description: Various styles of Blues originating in the rural US South, typically relying on expressive vocal delivery and featuring simple, usually acoustic instrumentation.

sub_genres.name: Electric Blues
sub_genres.description: Major development in sound and reach of Blues when it became possible to amplify the instruments of small combos.

sub_genres.name: Fife and Drum Blues
sub_genres.description: Rooted in martial Fife and Drum Corps music, originated among Afro-American communities in Mississippi.

sub_genres.name: Jump Blues
sub_genres.description: Emerged in the late 1930s with influence from Jazz styles such as Swing and Big Band, featuring fast tempos and raucous performances.

sub_genres.name: Piano Blues
sub_genres.description: Features the piano as a lead instrument performed solo or with a small ensemble, ranging from mid-tempo ballads to fast-paced dance styles.

sub_genres.name: Soul Blues
sub_genres.description: Shares similarities with Soul and incorporates the eponymous soulful inflections of Gospel, Jump Blues and soul into the vocals.
